While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling ready to wear clothing and shoe products in the local community. Jeneper has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jeneper joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeneper is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Jeneper from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to buy and sell

loans.name: Parsitau Ole

texts.en:
Parsitau S., aged 40 years, trades livestock in Enkaroni market in Kitengela. He sells his livestock to Kenya meat commission suppliers and to butchers in Kitengela and Kajiado for slaughter. He is married to Simayiyian S., a farmer who is 37 years old. Together they have two children, Salaash, age 22, who is a farmer and Jane, age 20, who is in college. He has been running his livestock trading business for one year and receives a monthly profit of Kshs. 11,000.

Parsitau was introduced to KADET LTD by the credit officer in charge of Kitengela office.  With the Kshs. 20,000 loan, Parsitau plans to use Kshs. 10,000 to buy cows, Kshs. 5,000 to buy goats and Kshs. 5,000 to buy sheep for trading.  If the loan boosts business, he will open a butchery in Kajiado town.

Parsitau’s dream is to develop his livestock trading business and open many butcheries in Kajiado, Kitengela and Bissil. He describes himself as hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy cows, sheep, and goats for trading.

loans.name: Mariafe

texts.en:
In 2008, Maria Fe found a chance to acquire business capital. She joined ASHI, the first kiva field partner, and she was encouraged by the stories of poor women of ASHI. She wanted to become successful like them and use loans in her business.  Because of the opportunity of receiving loans, Maria was able to start a business buying and selling vegetables.  She is courageous enough to take all the risk of running a business.  She thought she could be successful because her husband is there to support her and because of a dream she kept in her mind of having all of her children finish their schooling through the completion of college. 

Now she is requesting a new loan for the amount of 25,000 PHP. The loan fund will be used to pay for inventories of vegetables. She believes with more stock she will attract more customers in their village.

Maria Fe has never hoped for anything more than for her family and her children not to experience the hard life she and her husband has experienced. She dreams of building a new concrete and spacious house and expanding the business. 
 
Maria Fe’s one hope and dream is to alleviate her family from poverty. Maria Fe is very pleased to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for helping fund her business endeavor.

loans.use: To pay for inventories of vegetables.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan P. is from the village of San Fermin, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 39 years old. Joan is married and has 9 school-aged children. To make a living, Joan owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing rubber bushing in the local community. Joan has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Joan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Joan is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Joan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Leonilo

texts.en: Leonilo B. is from the village of Sagrada Familia, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 43 years old. Leonilo is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Leonilo plants and harvests rice for sale. Leonilo has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 22,000 Philippines peso (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Leonilo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonilo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Leonilo is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Leonilo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

location.town: Sagrada Familia, Tambulig, Zamboanga del sur

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel M. M., age 22, is newly married to Rebecca Nyobaki and runs a taxi business in the Huruma and Eastleigh estates. These are very busy estates as most people there use taxis as a means of transport. He was introduced to Kadet by other existing clients.

Samuel has been running his business for four years and earns a monthly profit of 40,000 Kenyan shillings. He intends to use the loan to buy spare parts for his car and service it. If the loan boosts his business, he will buy another car for his business and employ another driver to operate it.

Samuel aspires to have a fleet of taxis operating in different parts of Nairobi.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to service his car

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en:
Gideon has been practicing mixed farming for 12 years in Kisii town, western Kenya. He has employed one permanent employee and two casual laborers. His farm produces maize, beans, tea, milk, vegetables and onions, which are sold through the Kenya Tea Development Authority and the local market. He is also a photographer and additionally earns income from renting his oxen out for plowing to the local farmers. 

He has requested this loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He hopes that the extra income from this loan will enable him to purchase a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The extra income from this loan will go toward the education of his children. His biggest challenges have been pests and diseases, which affect his production, and transport problems. In the future, he hopes to own at least three quality dairy cows and open a mini studio in his town.

Gideon is 36 years old. He is married with three children, ages 4 months and 5 and 8 years. Two of the children are currently attending school.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Emelia's Group

texts.en:
Emelia A., from the village of Calaocan Santiago, is the 47-year-old group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Emelia, who is married and has three grown children, has been raising pigs for fattening and sale for over six years and earns approximately 4000 PHP each time she sells a raised animal.

In 2010, Emelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 4000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies, she is now requesting her second loan for 8000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. Emelia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Rena

texts.en:
Rena P. is from the village of Cabuan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Rena is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Rena owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, snack foods and canned goods in the local community. Rena has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rena is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel G. M., age 27, is married to Mary, and together they have a 1 year old child. He lives in Kiwanja near Kenyatta University where he also runs his business.
	
Samuel has been running a retail shop for four years and earns a monthly profit of 10,000 KES, which he uses to cater for the basic needs in the house. He was introduced to Kadet by the loan officer in charge of the Thika Road office.

After getting this loan, Samuel intends to buy stocks of cooking oil and fat, sugar, rice and flour to uplift his business and increase his profit. If the loan boosts business, Samuel plans to use the extra income to increase his inventory and grow his business to become a wholesaler.

Samuel, who has very happy customers, is hardworking and has big dreams for the future.

loans.use: To buy stocks of cooking oil and fat, sugar, rice and flour

loans.name: Joseph Maina

texts.en:
Joseph Maina K. is 32 years old. He is married to Lucy and together they have one son. Joseph has been operating a farm for about two years and earns an income of 8000 KES. Lucy helps on their farm as well.

He is taking his first loan with Kadet to buy fertilizer and dairy feeds. In the future, he hopes to buy land and build rental houses with the hopes of improving his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and dairy feeds

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas M. N., age 40, is married to Alice Koki, a business lady. His primary business is transporting people using motorcycles, a business popularly known as ‘’bodaboda’’ in Kenya. Thomas’ customers come and go from Matuu to Tala for business, and they are well-served by his comfortable transportation. He was introduced to Kadet by the credit officer in charge of Tala office.

Thomas has been running this business for four years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs 17000. With the loan he plans to buy another motorcycle. If the loan boosts business, he will save the extra money until he can afford to buy a bus to operate.

Thomas describes himself as hardworking. In the future, he hopes to buy many buses for his business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita A. is from the village of Mangidkid Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old and married with two adult children. To make a living, Teresita owns a retail store selling daily use products such as biscuits, candies, snacks, canned goods, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3300 PHP a month.

In 2008, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30000 PHP from GDMPCand is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kan

texts.en: Kan S. is a 24-year-old village woman who has a job as a fish seller. Her husband (pictured) repairs vehicles. The couple has one child. Kan S. buys fish from wholesale suppliers and other fisherman and sells retail. She earns approximately of $3 a day. The main income for her family comes from her husband who wants to buy old or second-hand motorbikes to fix and resell to make more profit. She said that she wishes to encourage her husband’s business, but does not have enough money, which is why she is asking for a loan.

loans.use: To buy an old motorcycle to fix up and sell.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter W. M., age 42, decorates vehicles for a living. His car decoration business is situated in Ngara market which is near the center of Nairobi. Many garages are located in this area, so he has a great opportunity for his business. He is married to Mary who is a business lady, and they have one child aged 12. Peter was introduced to Kadet by another Kadet client.

Peter has been running his business for twenty years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs 9000. With this loan, he wants to use Kshs 25000 to buy stickers and Kshs 5000 to advertise his business. If the loan boosts the business, Peter will increase his stock of stickers and eventually will buy a piece of land for farming. Peter describes himself as hard-working.

loans.use: To buy stickers for car decorations to advertise his business.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya. She has been farming for twenty-five years and employs 3 to 5 farmhands depending on the season. Her farm produces milk, bananas, maize, beans, and horticultural products which she sells at a nearby market. She depends on the income from her farm to cater to the basic needs of her family. Virginia is 53 years old and married with five adult children. Two of the children are currently attending school.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000KES to purchase a water pump and farming supplies. She says that this water pump will help her do more farming as she can water her farm even during a drought. She says that her biggest challenges have been inadequate capital, unpredictable weather, and diseases which affect her crops. In future, she would like to acquire more dairy cows and start a business of buying and selling farm produce.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump and farming supplies.

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Magdaline is a 59 year-old married woman who supports a family of nine. She is married to Danson Kandagor who is a gardener for Sacho High School. She has seven children aged between 28 and 9. She has been selling charcoal for 10 years and earns a monthly income of around Kshs 8000. She will use her loan to purchase more charcoal and expand her business. With the anticipated profits, she would like to open a retail shop.

This is her first loan with Kadet, and her hope is to open a retail shop and to ensure her children receive an education.

loans.use: Purchase charcoal

loans.name: Maingi

texts.en:
Maingi W., 50 years old, runs a tailoring shop in Kwa Njenga, which is a slum area. He is married to Doris and they have three children aged 19, 16, and 13 years. He was introduced to Kadet by existing customers.

Maingi has been running this business for three years, and his monthly profit is Kshs 18000. With the loan, he plans to buy fabrics for making clothes. If the loan boosts the business he will open another tailoring shop in another town and employ more tailors.

Since all of Maingi's children are in shool and require school fees, he dreams of opening a tailoring training school in his shop so as to earn more profit. This will help him to better meet his family's needs. He describes himself as ambitious.

loans.use: To buy additional fabrics for making clothes.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel M. N. is 34 years old, married, and has two children. He sells second-hand shoes in the Kenol open air market in Muranga.  He has been in the business for 10 years and earns a profit of about 3,000  KES per month.

He is applying for his third loan from KADET having repaid the other loans.  He will use the loan to  expand his business by adding more stock of  shoes to sell during the festive season.  He hopes to buy land and build his residential home and expand his business.

loans.use: To add more stock of shoes to sell

loans.name: Gregory Kiplimo

texts.en: Gregory K. is 41 years old, married, and has four children, ranging in age from eight to 16.  He is from Vihiga.  Gregory has a livestock rearing business that he has been doing for the past five years. He is applying for his sixth loan from KADET and has a good credit history. He will use the money to buy three bulls to raise and sell later. His profits will be used to repay the loan and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, Gregory hopes to establish a dairy milk cooling plant in the future.

loans.use: To buy three bulls to add to his stock

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson S. S. is 24, married, and has one child.  His wife is a farmer.  He trades livestock in the Bissil market in Kajiado. He sells his livestock to the Kenya meat commission and to butchers in the area for slaughter. He also supplies his cattle to the Bama Market, which is a large slaughterhouse. He has been running his livestock trading business for five years and he earns a monthly profit of  8,000 KES.

Wilson was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Kitengela office. With the 30,000 loan KES, Wilson plans to use 20,000 KES to buy cows, 5,000 KES to buy goats, and 5,000 KES to buy sheep, all for trading. If the loan boosts the business, Wilson will buy a pick-up truck for transporting the livestock. Wilson's dream is to specialize in supplying livestock to Dagorreti and Kenya meat commission slaughterhouses. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy livestock for trading

loans.name: Bonface Nyabela

texts.en:
Bonface Nyabera I., age 35, runs a motorcycle transport business at Rongai popularly known as 'bodaboda'. Rongai is a very busy place as the main means of transport in the area is the motorcycle transport. He is married to Beatrice, and together they have three primary school children. He was introduced to Kadet by Kadet existing customers.

Bonface has been running his business for two years and his monthly profit is Kshs 25000. When he receives a loan, he will buy purchase another motorcycle and employ another worker to operate it. With the increased profits, Bonface will buy a piece of land and build a house where he can live with his family. 

Bonface describes himself as hardworking and dreams of having rental houses to increase his income in the future.

loans.use: To buy another motorcycle for his business.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul K. is a 36 year-old horticultural farmer in Jomvu Mombasa. He is married to Ethel Mwaka, and they have  four children.

Paul has been in this business for the last twenty one years and has done well. With his first loan from KADET, he would like to purchase water pipes and seeds for his nursery and use the anticipated profit to boost his wife’s grocery business. 

He hopes to succeed through KADET loans.

loans.use: To purchase water pipes and seeds for his nursery.

loans.name: Julius Kimaiyo

texts.en:
Julius A. is 63 years old from Kapkures in Vihiga. He is married to Sally, a poultry farmer, and together they have one daughter.

Julius has run a business of rearing livestock for the past 5 years and earns around Kshs 19,900 per month.. He is applying for his sixth loan from Kadet Ltd and has a good credit history. Julius intends to use the money to expand his cattle stock by buying three dairy cows and renewing his trade license as well.

His hope and desire is to establish a cattle ranch and to be able to supply the Kenya Meat Commission.

loans.use: To buy three dairy cows.

loans.name: Christina's Group

texts.en:
Christina Nadim A. lives in Lahore which is Pakistan’s second largest city and known for its history and culture. She lives there in the area named R-A Bazar with her family in a 2 room brick house. She moved there 2 years ago. Christina is a very talented lady who owns and operates a beauty salon in her her home. She provides beauty treatments to her customers and also sometimes sews clothes in her spare time.  

Christina is married to N. A. who has a business of selling plumbing supplies in the market. He has been doing this business for over 14 years and handles a good number of customers. 

Christina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy plumbing supplies such as water pipes and taps etc in bulk quantity to fulfill larger orders on time and to increase his income. Christina is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In previous loan years, she has paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called the Asasah Passbook) is Christina.

loans.use: To buy plumbing supplies for sale.

loans.name: Tinga Ole Lesiyio

texts.en:
Tinga has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last 11 years.  He is 26 years old, married to Sempeyo Ene Tinga and they have one child.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 1st loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy 10 calves which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

In the  future,Tinga hopes to have a big animal farm and to become a leading supplier  of beef in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy 10 calves which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Glarah Chepkemoi

texts.en:
Glarah S. is 52, married, and has eight children. Some of the children have finished school while others are still in school. Glarah began her business five years ago in her village where she collects tea leaves from farmers, transports them to the factory, and sells them at a profit.

Glarah learned about KADET through a friend who is also a KADET client. With this first loan, she plans to expand her business and acquire more tea leaves from farmers so that she can increase her supply to the factory resulting in higher profits.  Her future plan is to own a lorry to transport her tea leaves to the factory; which will boost her business.

loans.use: To expand her business of buying and selling tea leaves

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia D. is from the village of Brgy. Maddiangat, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 53 years old, married, and has five adult children. To make a living, Emilia owns and operates a business raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising ducks to produce and sell eggs. Emilia has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Emilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. That loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Emilia is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional animals. This loan will be Emilia's fourth loan from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support the immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional animals

loans.name: Perlyn

texts.en:
Perlyn P. sells vegetables, a business she finds very productive. She learned the business from experience and using her own initiative in dealing with costumers. The proceeds of her business are a big help to the family, especially in meeting the basic needs of her family, allowing them to enjoy life in a simple way.

Perlyn is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP from Kiva partner, ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.). She will use the loan to buy more vegetables. Having additional inventory will give her family additional income and will allow her to expand her business.

Perlyn is determined to improve her business venture as well as the life of her family. Knowing that she can access financial support through loans has given her courage and faith that someday her only son will graduate from college and be ready to face his own life. Perlyn also aspires to build a beautiful home to live in. She is hoping that with ASHI and Kiva’s support there is a possibility that her family can fulfill their dreams.

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Melody C. is from the village of Brgy. Maddiangat, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 36 years old. Melody is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Melody owns and operates a retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling rice in the local community. Melody has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Melody joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melody is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Melody from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Selly Jepketer

texts.en:
Selly is a fifty-two year-old mother of five children and married to Mr.L.. Three of her children are married and two still go to school. She is in the business of selling new clothes at her village. She also practices dairy farming and sells milk at the town center where some of her neighbors also buy from her.

She plans to use her first loan to buy additional new clothes so that she can sell to her customers at a profit.  Her future plan is to own a shop at the town center and stock it with new clothes as she has a good number of customers who visit her and make orders.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Ngaru Ole

texts.en:
Ngaru has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last three years.  He is 51 years old, married to Tajiri Ene K. and they have three children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan to buy goats and sheep which he will sell later at a profit.

In the future, Ngaru hopes to be a large scale supplier of animals in Naivasha town and be able to make enough cash so that he can enroll his children in a better school.

loans.use: To buy goats and sheep which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Bernabe

texts.en:
Bernabe C. is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. She is 52 years old. Bernabe is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Bernabe owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Bernabe has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Bernabe joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernabe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. Bernabe is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Bernabe from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of the borrower's family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Timothy

texts.en:
Timothy is 31 years old and single. He is a farmer from the town of Murang'a in central Kenya. He has been in the farming business for three years and employs one farm hand. His farm produces maize, beans, and chickens, which he sells locally. He solely depends on the income from his farm to cater for his needs. His biggest challenge has been the lack of a stable market for his products.

He has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo of 50,000 KES to expand his rabbit and poultry farming. He says that these projects will increase his income and enable him to start a family. In the future, he would like to do intensive dairy farming by acquiring at least five dairy cows and expanding his poultry business to enable him to sell at least 500 chickens every month. He encourages Juhudi to continue with its good work.

loans.use: To expand his rabbit and poultry farming.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan, aged 39, is a married mother of two children, ages sixteen and seven, respectively. Her husband is a farmer who specializes in dairy farming and supplies different customers.

Susan has been buying and selling maize for five years and has been earning good profits from this business, especially when the supply is low and demand is high. She was introduced to Kadet by an existing client. With this first loan she plans to buy additional bags of maize since this is the season when prices are low.

Her future plan is to own a lorry, which she will use to transport maize bags to her customers, which will improve efficiency and customer satisfaction.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize for resale.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses M. is 36 years old. He operates a shop selling electrical appliances to his customers in Vikwatani Mombasa. He is married to Purity and together they are blessed with one child. He has been in this business for the last 14 years and has done great. He is requesting his first loan from KADET to purchase more electrical appliances and will use the anticipated profits to boost his business. Moses hopes to buy a plot of land in the future.

loans.use: To  purchase more electrical appliances.

loans.name: Joseph Samuel Mwangi

texts.en:
Joseph K., age 34 years, runs a hotel (restaurant) business at Dagoretti, which is a middle-class estate with a good population. He is married to Jane Ngumbi and together they have two grown-up children, a daughter and a son, aged 26 and 18 years. He was introduced to Kadet by an old Kadet client.

Joseph has been running this hotel for one year and his monthly profit is KES 8000. With the loan of KES 40,000 he will buy flour, cooking fat, and charcoal, and pay the salaries of his three employees. If the loan boosts the business, Joseph plans to buy a gas cooker to make cooking faster in his hotel so as not to delay his customers.

Joseph, who describes himself as hardworking, has a dream of buying a piece of land to build rental houses as well as building his own house.

loans.use: To buy flour, cooking fat, and charcoal.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna U., 34, is from the village of San Roque, Maramag, Bukidnon. Edna is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Edna owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk foods & canned goods in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Edna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Edna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Edna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

In the future, Reson hopes to build rental houses to supplement her income.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva N. lives in the Ntinda neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  She also takes care of additional family members (sisters). Eva has a business of poultry farming.  She has been in this business for six years, and she works all seven days of the week.  Eva sells her products from home, by means of retail.  Eva has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of chicken feeds. She also generates additional income through operating a restaurant. Eva's main business challenges are seasonality, transportation of chicken feeds and poultry diseases.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own 1,500 chicken layers. Eva lives in a house that she owns; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of chicken feeds

loans.name: Nguyễn

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị (20201030006) is a 71-year-old woman who lives in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has 6 adult children.  To making a living, L. owns and operates a business in which she makes and sells bamboo products to local businesses and community members.  L. has been engaged in this business for over 26 years and earns approximately 4.300.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  L. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6.944.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products.  L. is now requesting a new loan of 8.736.000 VND to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be L.'s fifth loan from SEDA.  L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


L. Nguyễn Thị (20201030006) là 71 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 6 trẻ ở độ tuổi trưởng thành.  Để kiếm sống, L. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ sản xuất & bán các sản phẩm bằng tre cho các doanh nghiệp và người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  L. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 26 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, L. kiếm được khoảng 4.300.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2007, L. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  L. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua nguyên liệu thô để sản xuất các sản phẩm bổ sung.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.736.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua nguyên liệu thô để sản xuất các sản phẩm bổ sung.  Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  L. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia T. is from the town of Palilan, Jimenez Mis. Occ. Philippines. She is 60 years old and is single. To make a living, Julia owns and operates a retail seafood store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community.  Julia has been engaged in her business for over 40 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Julia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business. Julia is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Julia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell in her store.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther G. is currently in the business of selling sugar, onions, rice and beans  and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and sugar to sell.  Esther is 30 years old and is married with a husband that is a boda-boda. She has 5 children and her children all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more bags of rice and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana M. is from the village of Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City. She is 44 years old. Juana is widowed and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Juana owns and operates a transportation business.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle transport services in the local community.  Juana has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Juana joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. Juana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in renovating the motorcycle. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Juana from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in renovating the motorcycle used in her transport business.

loans.name: Christopher Makanga

texts.en:
Christopher has operated his motorcycle for transportation in Naivasha town for the last two years.  He is 42 years old, married to Joyce Keya and they have three children together.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan after he paid his first loan well and in good time.  He plans to use the current loan amount to open a milk bar as a secondary business and sell different types of milk products including; yogurt, fresh milk, and sour milk.

In future, Christopher hopes to grow his milk bar and stock it with the latest milk processing machines.

loans.use: To open a milk bar and sell different types of milk products

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth K. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has seven children, two of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her late brother’s children).  Ruth has a poultry farming business.  She has been in this business for nine years and she works 7 days out of every week. Ruth sells her products in a market, by means of wholesale/retail.    

Ruth has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy poultry feeds and medicine. She also generates additional income through crop  farming.

The main business challenges for Ruth include thieves and the high cost of chicken feed.  Her goals and aspirations are finishing her house and paying school fees for her children.  Ruth lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, electricity and water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of chicken feed.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is requesting for KES 50,000 loan to buy textbooks, dictionaries, Kamusi (kiswahili dictionary), revision books and other stationery to add to her stock. She has been operating PK Booksellers where she sells books at a stall for the last 8 years. Her business environment is busy and her customers are parents and students.  Veronica is 31 years old, married and a mother of two.

She describes herself as a visionary and honest and hopes to open other outlets and expand her business to other areas. She says that Faulu loans have helped her grow her business.

loans.use: Buying textbooks, dictionaries, Kamusi (kiswahili dictionary), revision books and other stationery

loans.name: Nguyễn

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị (20201030010) is a 27 year-old woman who lives in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, L. sells electronic products in the local community.  L. has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3.200.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  L. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5.152.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  L. is now requesting a new loan of 8.288.000 VND which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital.  The loan will be Lien's 5th loan from SEDA.  L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


L. Nguyễn Thị (20201030010) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, L. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm điện tử trong cộng đồng địa phương.  L. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, L. kiếm được khoảng 3.200.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2007, L. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  L. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua thêm hàng hóa tồn kho & vốn lưu động.  Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  L. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 64 years old, a mother of three children and a widow.  Her business involves buying bags of maize at her village and transporting them to bigger centers to resell at a profit. She also does dairy farming and sells her milk to neighbors and the rest she sells at the nearest center.
.
She learned about Kadet through an existing client. With this first loan she plans to purchase bags of maize which she will sell at a profit. Her future plan is to own a lorry which she will be using to transport the bags of maize for resale.

loans.use: To purchase bags of maize for resale.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene O. is from the village of Kinuman Norte, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Irene is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Irene owns and operates a transportation services business.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating service-based services. Irene has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Irene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Irene is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to repair the existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Irene from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair the existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Creselda

texts.en:
Creselda R. is from the village of Locsoon Tudela Misamis occidental. She is 34 years old. Creselda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Creselda owns and operates a business raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Creselda has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Creselda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Creselda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC.  Creselda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Creselda from GDMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Kinkirri Topoika

texts.en:
Kinkirri has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha for the last two years.  He is 30 years old, married to Wesionka Ene Shonkom and they have 3 children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 1st loan.  He plans to buy a motorbike and use it for transporting people and goods from one place to another.  

In the future, Kinkirri hopes both businesses, livestock farming and motorcycle transport will grow to provide him substantial income so that he can comfortably put his children through school.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transportation.

loans.name: Ruth Andeso

texts.en:
Ruth A. is 48 years old,  married, and has two adult children. They live in Eregi area in Vihiga.  Ruth has a cereal business, which she has been doing for the past four years. She is applying for her fourth loan from KADET after successfully repaying her previous ones. Ruth will use the money to buy 15 sacks of maize to add to her stock. Her monthly income is 13,500 KES.

In the future, Ruth hopes to acquire a posho-mill (grinding machine).

loans.use: To purchase sacks of maize

loans.name: Lê

texts.en:

N. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 18 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, N. kiếm được khoảng 3.300.000 VND một tháng.

N. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thức ăn & đồ uống cho nhà hàng.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.736.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua thức ăn & đồ uống cho nhà hàng.  Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  N. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To purchase food & drinks for the restaurant

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta B. is from the village of Brgy.Sto.Domingo, Bambang,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 59 years old. Marietta is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Marietta owns and operates a specialized retail store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Marietta has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marietta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marietta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marietta is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 3nd loan taken out by Marietta from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering.

This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Emily from GDMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Peter Gitimu

texts.en:
Peter is 43 years old and divorced with one son. He owns a rice farm in Embu and has been in the business for 29 years. He earns an income of 15,000 KES a month.

He is taking his 3rd loan with Kadet. He wants to use the loan to lease an extra half acre, buy fertilizer, fungicides, and pay for labour.  He hopes to make his son happy and help him attain his goals in the future. He also hopes to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To lease an extra half acre, buy fertilizer, fungicides, and pay for labour.

loans.name: Nguyễn

texts.en:
T. Nguyễn Thị T. (20201030012) is a 39-year-old woman living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. T. owns and operates a business, manufacturing and selling products to local businesses and community members. T. has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000,000 VND a month from it.

In 2007, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,048,000 VND from SEDA, which was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. T. is now requesting a new loan of 8,736,000 VND which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the 5th loan taken out by T. from SEDA.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


T. Nguyễn Thị T. (20201030012) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, T. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên T. nhập, mà nguồn T. nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ sản xuất & bán các sản phẩm được chế tạo thông thường cho các doanh nghiệp và người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  T. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 2 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, T. kiếm được khoảng 4.000.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2007, T. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  T. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua nguyên liệu thô để sản xuất các sản phẩm bổ sung.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.736.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua nguyên liệu thô để sản xuất các sản phẩm bổ sung.  Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  T. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn T. nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có T. nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . loans.name: Đặng

texts.en:
H.  Đặng Thị (20201030017) is a 37-year-old female living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has 4 school-aged children. H. owns & operates a business, generating income from providing general services to local community members. H. has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3.800.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.704.000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to invest in renovating the business. H. is now requesting a new loan of 8.736.000 VND which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be her 5th loan from SEDA.  H. plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support immediate members of her family.

About SEDA:
The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

About GDMPC:

loans.name: Hannah Miloyo

texts.en:
Hannah A., 62 years old, is from Chavano area in Vihiga. She is married to Chrispo and they have one daughter, Dorosila, who is 20 years old.

Hannah, a farmer, has a big maize plantation and is applying for her fourth loan to enable her to buy more maize seedlings for the next plantation. Her monthly income is Kshs 9,900. The profits made from this business will be used to pay college fees for her daughter.

Hannah's desire is to diversify into livestock rearing in the future.

loans.use: To buy more maize seedlings to plant

loans.name: Richard Nderitu

texts.en:
Richard has operated his retail shop selling electronic goods in the town of Naivasha for the last 20 years. He is 50 years old, married to Beatrice Wanjiru, and together they have five children.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend, and this will be his second loan. He repaid his previous loan of Kshs 50,000 well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy more electronics for sale in his shop.

In the future, Richard hopes to construct his own building in Naivasha and rent office space.

loans.use: To buy more electronics to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Badegna Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe BADEGNA sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 6 enfants. Elles vivent dans les familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Ces femmes résident dans le  quartier Massabla-coura de la ville de  BOUGOUNI, (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Ces femmes se sont connues par des relations de commerce. 
Dans l’intention d’acheter plus de produits pour satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur sixième prêt de groupe, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce  nouveau prêt,  DJENEBA D., la présidente du groupe  compte acheter, une importante quantité de différentes sortes de condiments alimentaires auprès des grossistes à Bamako.  Elle effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant et à crédit dans le grand marché de Bougouni et à domicile, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt  elle compte obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé dans l’activité et l’autre partie dans les frais d’éducation des enfants.
texts.en:
The women of Badegna Group are all married. On average, they are 35 years old and have six children.  They live in large traditional families with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children and husbands. They live in the neighborhood of Massabla-Coura of the city of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They have known each other through business relations.

In order to buy more products to meet the demand from their customers, they decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is their sixth group loan, after having properly repaid all their previous loans. Djeneba D., the group's president, will use her new loan to buy a large quantity of various kinds of food condiments. She will buy her supplies from wholesalers in Bamako and retail them for cash or credit at the great market in Bougouni as well as from her home. Her customers are usually women.

Thanks to this loan, Djeneba D. expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 CFA francs. She will invest it partly in her business and spend it partly on her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy food condiments

loans.name: Enock Lerionka

texts.en:
Enock K. is 38 years old and from Shartoka, a village in Kilgoris. He is married to Irene and together they have four children between the ages of 7 and 1 years old.

Enoch is a farmer and mostly plants maize. He is in need of maize seeds and also wishes to hire one person to help him.  He is applying for his first loan from Kadet Ltd to enable him buy the seeds. Enoch plans to use the profits made from this business to care for his family's needs and to also pay for school fees for his school age children. His monthly income is KES 10,000.

He wants to expand his business and farming and to be able to produce as much maize as possible so that he can earn more profit that will enable him to improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To buy maize seeds.

Perlie D. is from the village of Corales, Jimenez,Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old. Perlie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Perlie owns and operates a general store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Perlie has been engaged in her business for over 1 year  and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Perlie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Perlie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Perlie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:

To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a business raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.  Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.  This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Evelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Manson

texts.en:
Manson is a single man who lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is paying school fees for his younger siblings.

He operates an electronic shop, selling spare parts for repairing televisions, radios and mobile phones.  His potential customers are passersby and neighbours.  Manson faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes to expand his electronics shop and sell wholesale. 

He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business. With the KES 20,000 he wants to purchase spare parts and equipment for repairing televisions, radios and mobile phones.

loans.use: To purchase spares parts and equipment for repairing televisions, radios and mobile phones.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Even at her older age of 41 years old, Gemma never feels tired of doing things to make money for her everyday living. Although her husband sometimes gives her some money from his income as a construction worker (laborer), Fe does not stop there.  She wants to help her family especially her two dependent children, who are still in school. That’s why she decided to join Kiva field partner, Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI).  She wants to get a loan to buy inventory such as frozen foods, silver accessories, and other supplies. 

Now that her business is up and running, Gemma need additional funds for the expansion of her business. She wants to increase her stock of goods that she sells in her house. This will make her business grow.

Gemma has a simple dream, making sure her family does not experience hardship, which will make her happy.  That’s why she will never get tired of helping them even in little ways. If these dreams will happen, Gemma also hopes to extend her helping hand to others, most especially her relatives who also need support.

Fe is very glad for the motivation and support, which give her strength to continue dreaming of the best in life.  Gemma is praying that, with ASHI and Kiva’s support, there is a big opportunity for them to reach their dreams.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of frozen foods, silver accessories and other supplies.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Lý Phan Thị (20201030015) is a 59-year-old female living in the town of huyện Yên Phong-Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has 3 adult children. Lý owns & operates a business providing general services to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over 18 years and earns approximately 3.600.000 VND a month.

In 2007, Lý joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.704.000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. Lý is now requesting a new loan of 8.736.000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her 5th loan from SEDA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Lý Phan Thị (20201030015) là 59 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 3 trẻ ở độ tuổi trưởng thành.  Để kiếm sống, Lý Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ nói chung cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Lý thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 18 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Lý kiếm được khoảng 3.600.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2007, Lý đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Lý đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thêm hàng hóa tồn kho & vốn lưu động.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.736.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  Lý dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business
